head.hi:
M. DE HUMBOLDT,
AND THE VOLCANOS OF MEXICO.

div.head: TO THE EDITOR OF THE COURIER.
div.p:
Sir—Having travelled in New Spain, and knowing, from what
I have seen and experienced, the inestimable value and correct-
ness of M. de Humboldt’s works, I felt not a little surprised to hear
that distinguished traveller constantly accused of exaggeration
and inaccuracy. If those, who thus endeavor to detract from the
merits of M. de Humboldt’s work, are not so alive to the beauties
of nature as he is, we must recollect, that there is, perhaps, no
man now existing, who combines with the depth and details of
almost every ſcience, so much general knowledge; and to such a
mind, that may have the greatest value, which, by ordinary and
superficial observers, would be slightly noticed, because they are
unable to appreciate it. As, however, I had heard M. de Hum-
boldt accused of asserting a deliberate falsehood, which no warmth
of feeling, or liveliness of imagination, could justify; as I have in
vain endeavored to combat the interpretation often put upon the
passage alluded to; and as an attack has been made upon him in
a work recently published—(Bullock’s Mexico, vide note at the
end of chap. vii.)—on coming to Paris, and having had the
honor and pleasure of making M. de Humboldt’s acquaintance,
I ventured to mention the subject to him, and then he very kindly
addressed to me the enclosed.

J’ai dit dans l’edition originale Francaise Essai Politique,
in 4to. T. 1. p. 80, Introd. p. 17.

“Pour mieux distinguer les volcans actives des volcans eteints,
je me suis permis d’ajouter une petite colonne de fumée aux dessins
du Pic d’Orizaba et du Grand Volcan de la Puebla, quoique je
n’aie observé cette fumée ni à Xalapa ni à Mexico. Nous avons
vu sortir une grande masse de cendres et des vapeurs trés denses
de la bouche du Popocatepetl le 24 Juin 1804 dans la plaine de
Tetimba, prés de San Nicolas de los Ranchos.”

“Le Popocatepetl forme un cone enorme dont le cratére, con-
stamment enflammé, jettant de la fumée et des cendres s’ouvre au
milieu des neiges eternelles!”

Ce passage n’indique certainement pas que l’on voit de la fumée
de Mexico même; il dit, que le cratére jette encore tous les ans,
j’aurois pu dire tous les mois, de la fumée; elle se voit dans la
plaine de Tetimba, au pic du volcan. Le tremblement de terre
du 13 Janvier 1804, fut accompagné d’une forte ejection de cendres
et de fumée. Les ejections sont trés communes au mois de Mai
et entres entre 4 et 6 heures du soir. La direction de la fumée sert
même aux Indiens du voisinage de pronostic meteoroligique météorologique .

M. de Humboldt serait très reconnoissant à Monsieur Staple-
ton, s’il vouloit bien repandre ces éclaircissemens; car il tient
beaucoup plus à la reputation d’un voyageur veredique verédique qu’à
celle de l’esprit et du savoir.

By this it will appear, that, in that faithful and beautiful de-
scription, (T. 1. p. 179, chap. viii.) of the view to be seen on a fine
morning from the tower of the cathedral of Mexico, or from the
hill of Chapultepetl, M. de H. does not mean to say that he has
seen from either of those points the smoke issuing from the crater
of Popocatepetl, but only that it is constantly inflamed, that smoke
does issue from it, and that he himself, when near to the crater,
was present with M. Bonpland at an eruption of smoke and
ashes. The greatest wonders of our globe being to the inhabitants
of New Spain an every-day scene, they are less alive to them
than the stranger, who is surprised, on enquiring after the cu-
riosities in their immediate vicinity, (to see which he has crossed
the Atlantic), to find them often ignorant even of their existence.
I had in vain made various and anxious enquiries at Mexico res-
pecting the activity of the volcano of Popocatepetl—all agreed,
that there had been no eruption within the last century. At last,
one morning, when I was riding before breakfast from Mexico
to the Penol de los Banos, I met an Indian, who, in reply to
my questions, told me, that during the dry season, when the wind
blew from the North, he had occasionally seen the smoke even
from the city of Mexico! In Europe, we must be surprised to
hear, that such a fact should only be known to an Indian; but
that surprise will cease, when we consider the indolence and
indifference of the enlightened classes in that country, and the
immense distance from Mexico of the summit of a mountain,
which rises into the Heavens near 18,000 feet above the level of
the sea, covered with eternal snows, and for ever inaccessible to
man.

Cortez, in his letters, A.D. 1519, alludes to the smoke of
Popocatepetl.

A grand eruption, which took place in 1540 is mentioned by
Gormora.—(Hist. Mex. published 1553.)
The last great eruption, according to Torquemada, was in 1594.

I subjoin some extracts of M. de H.’s Journal, which have
not yet been published, and which he has very obligingly com-
munnicated to me:—

“The rock of Popocatepetl is obsidian-porphyry. The crater
itself is easily to be seen with a glace; but as it inclines towards
the East (as all the great volcanic cones in these parts do), it is
not visible from the city of Mexico. The smell of suphureoussulphureous
vapours can be perceived below the limit of the snow. These
vapours are regarded by the Indians as a presage of weather.
When, in the evening, a black smoke arises from the crater, and
forms itself into a cloud, inclining to the North, it is thought to
portend rain; when it inclines to the South, it is looked upon as
the forerunner of a severe frost; when it arises perpendicularly,
it is said to announce a storm. At times, two or three hours
before the storm is felt in the inferior regions, clouds of
pumice-stone and ashes arise from the crater, and they may
be seen rolling downwards upon the snow, as particles of
sand. There was a violent storm accompanying the earth-
quake on the 13th of January, 1804, and a considerable
eruption of smoke and ashes from the mouth of the crater.
The smoke is seldom to be seen in the morning; generally
from four to six in the evening, particularly at the setting
of the sun, and more frequently in the month of May. The
Indians assured me, that at that period, the whole top some-
times assumes a red-yellowish color, which may be attributed
to the sulphurcous vapours. At night, however, no fire has ever
been seen within the memory of man.”

Those who have visited the volcanoes of the New World, and
of the West Indian Islands, know, that this state of constant
inflammation, and emission of smoke, is common to almost all
of them. I descended last year, into the crater of that of Gua-
daloupe, (the elevation of which is near 6,000 feet above the
level of the sea,) and had my hands scorched in procuring
some of the burning sulphur, which glimmers of a bright yel-
low, through the clouds of smoke in different parts
of the interior of the crater. In the Island of Dominica,
I have seen several burning craters of the same descrip-
tion. Such also was precisely the state of the volcano
of St. Vincent’s before the remarkable eruption of 1812,
which covered ships with ashes at two or three hundred Eng-
lish miles to the windward, This has been endeavored to be explained by the counter-
currents of air prevalent in the Tropics, and blowing in a direction
contrary to that of the trade-winds. as well as the island of Bar-
badoes, at eighty miles distance, and the noise of which was
heard at Antigua, (and I believe at St. Thomas’s) where it was
thought to be an engagement between the two fleets of France
and Great Britain, though (wonderful to relate) not heard by
the inhabitants of the smaller islands in the immediate vici-
nity of St. Vincent’s itself. These burning mountains acquire
the greatest interest from the consideration, that though now ap-
parently in an almost passive state, they may, by convulsion,
become, when least expected, vast engins of the most horrible
destruction. The giving way of a layer of earth, undermined by
slow fire, may cause an eruption, and shake the universe.
